instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have a spotless board which won't turn on.
I assume those board should not need a battery to give me <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> as the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> do, am I correct?
I am expecting to get around 1amp with the bear board and then down to 0, even with no screen, no battery.

The board goes from 5V to 20V (draws .25A during the process) and then draws 0.17A for a second or 2, then 0.2A for another second and down to 0A where it stays.
Is there a possibility that this board needs a T2 Firmware update?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is a nice 12.6V.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power
threads.message:
You don't lose too much time trying to put in DFU restore.
Usually T2 firmware issue keeps <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12.3V, but god knows all behaviors can generate T2...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power
threads.message: FYI, it was just a battery issue. These boards need a battery or will have that behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power
threads.message:
Thanks for the feedback.
We still need to collect lot of information about about T2 boards....
